awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Plant-made antimicrobials used as a produce wash for vegetables and fruits
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a commercial-scale natural wash solution for produce.  The goal is to meet the needs of consumers for greener, environmentally sustainable products for safe, natural processing of agriculture products, food, and beverages. Consumers are requesting that sanitizers in food processing meet two key metrics:   1) they need to lead to a safer food supply, and 2) they need to be more environmentally friendly, and ideally derived from natural (non-chemical) sources. The proposed technology is designed to fill this gap as the formulations have durable activity for higher efficacy, conserve water, and enhance safety and shelf-life by greater reduction of foodborne pathogens and spoilage bacteria during transportation and storage. Target customers, such as large crop producers and processing / packaging / distribution companies, already deploy sanitizers, yet are often not satisfied with the current solutions.  This project seeks to discover how best to partner and meet customers’ need, with benefits of significant water savings, extended shelf-life, environmental sustainability, and possibly fewer recalls for produce as well as reduced illnesses and deaths from foodborne pathogens. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a natural antimicrobial wash technology that has been tested to kill foodborne pathogens such as Salmonella and E. coli O157:H7 on produce such as vegetables and fruits. In addition, the technology is designed to conserve wash water due to the recyclability of the wash water, and increase shelf-life of the produce, which may be considered eco-friendly. This technology combines plant extracts with emulsifiers to create synergistic effects that are active at very low concentrations to achieve these benefits. Processing houses are highly complex and adapted to each type of crop in the various steps such as coring, cutting, cleaning/sanitizing, and bagging of the produce. Customer discovery interviews and visits will allow development of a business model around the proposed technology to evaluate product-market fit. Overall, the proposed project will significantly advance the understanding of the pain points surrounding produce washing and how this natural plant-made antimicrobial wash technology may be implemented.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through NSF I-Corps, our team conducted extensive customer discovery to assess the market viability of an edible, natural sanitizer using fogging technology to reduce foodborne pathogens and mold, and extend the shelf-life of produce and meat. Over the course of the program, we conducted 167 interviews with key stakeholders, including farmers/producers, food processors, sanitizer manufacturers, retailers, and food safety experts. These interviews validated the demand for enhanced food safety solutions, particularly natural sanitizers over chemical-based alternatives, further driven by climate-related food system vulnerabilities and sustainability goals. Our prototype testing demonstrated that the fogging method effectively reduces pathogens and mold, conserves water, and preserves produce, including delicate produce, confirming a minimum viable product (MVP). The project uncovered strong commercialization potential, particularly in niche markets where adoption barriers are lower than in large-scale processing facilities.

Customer discovery revealed several key findings. Industry stakeholders confirmed a growing need for natural, scalable food safety solutions due to increasing regulatory pressures, climate change events, and supply chain disruptions. While large-scale processors face high barriers to adoption, smaller and specialty food producers expressed greater willingness to explore new sanitization methods. The transition from dip treatment to fogging provides distinct advantages, including water conservation, better coverage, and the ability to treat delicate produce that was previously unsuitable for traditional methods. Additionally, significantly longer shelf-life offers competitive advantages, such as reducing food waste, expanding market reach, and increasing distribution flexibility.

Technical validation was a key milestone. The prototype was successfully tested on meat, strawberries, and microgreens, confirming significant pathogen and mold reduction, and shelf-life extension. The method also demonstrated water efficiency, reducing dependency on traditional dip-based sanitization methods. With these promising results, the prototype is now ready for pilot-scale implementation with early adopters.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its advancement of food safety and post-harvest preservation technologies. Unlike traditional dip-based treatments, this fogging-based natural sanitization method provides enhanced pathogen and mold reduction, water conservation, and improved efficacy on produce and meat. The research contributes to the field of food microbiology and sustainable food processing by demonstrating how natural antimicrobials, applied via fogging, can effectively reduce foodborne pathogens and mold while minimizing product degradation. Additionally, the project provides new insights into industry adoption barriers through extensive customer discovery, bridging the gap between laboratory research and commercial application. These findings strengthen the scientific foundation for scalable, chemical-free sanitization methods, positioning the innovation for further development in the food industry.

Beyond the technical and commercial aspects, if successfully commercialized, this technology has a significant societal and economic impact. By enhancing food safety, it contributes to a safer food supply and helps mitigate risks associated with foodborne illnesses and outbreaks. The technology also supports sustainability goals by reducing food waste, conserving resources, and lowering greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, by extending shelf-life, it enables longer-distance food transportation, improved distribution flexibility, and greater market reach, offering economic benefits for food producers, retailers, and consumers.

The next steps for this project include conducting pilot programs with food producers and processors, securing additional funding and partnerships to support scale-up efforts, and further refining the commercialization pathway. Overall, the NSF I-Corps program played a crucial role in validating market needs, assessing commercialization potential, and positioning the technology for real-world impact.
